sect2.title: Introduction to Tcsh
sect2.para: The Tcsh package contains "an enhanced but completely compatible version of the Berkeley Unix C shell (csh)". This is useful as an alternative shell for those who prefer C syntax to that of the bash shell, and also because some programs require the C shell in order to install.

sect2.title: Installation of Tcsh
sect2.para: Install Tcsh by running the following commands:

userinput.command: ./configure --prefix=/usr && make && make install && make install.man && ln -sf /usr/bin/tcsh /bin/csh

sect2.title: Command explanations
sect2.para: ln -sf /usr/bin/tcsh /bin/csh: The FHS states that if there is a C shell installed, there should be a symlink from /bin/csh to it. This creates that symlink.

sect3.title: Config files
sect3.para: There are numerous configuration files for the C shell. Examples of these are /etc/csh.cshrc, /etc/csh.login, ~/.tcshrc, ~/.cshrc, ~/.history, ~/.login, ~/.cshdirs, /etc/csh.logout, ~/.logout and ~/.logout. More information on these files can be found in the tcsh(1) man page.

sect3.title: tcsh
sect3.para: tcsh is an enhanced but completely compatible version of the Berkeley Unix C shell, csh. It is usable as both an interactive shell and a script processor.
